para.paratext: The plaintiff in a medical malpractice case must present expert testimony which establishes the proper standard of care in the situation at issue and that the defendant's conduct was below this standard.[1] It is the expert's qualifications, rather than the defendant physician's specialty or practice area, that controls whether the trial court should allow the expert's testimony in medical malpractice action.[2]

For example, a trial court's admission of expert opinion testimony about negligent nursing care from a medical doctor was reversed in Piedmont Hosp., Inc. v. Milton,[3] because there was no showing that the doctor was “an expert competent to testify” in the field of nursing. He was not licensed in the same profession.

O.C.G.A. § 24-7-702(c)(2) requires the testifying expert in a medical malpractice action to have been “regularly engaged” in the area of practice or specialty in which the testimony is given for three of the last five years. However, in Dubois v. Brantley,[4] the Supreme Court opined that statutory construction did not render the expert's testimony inadmissible where he had only performed the exact procedure once during the previous five years, but had used the same methodology and was familiar with the procedure and the implements used. The Georgia Supreme Court has sustained constitutional challenges to O.C.G.A. § 24-7-702(c)(2) based on a plaintiff's right to trial by jury, equal protection, special privileges and immunities, separation of powers, and special law grounds.[5]

When testifying that a defendant physician breached the standard of care, a plaintiff's expert does not need to use “magic words”[6] nor does an expert need to testify that the defendant-physician was “guilty of malpractice or professional negligence” so long as the expert makes clear the defendant practiced medicine below the proper standard of care.[7]

In McNabb v. Landis,[8] the Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the trial court's exclusion of a medical expert's testimony about the care and treatment he himself would have rendered in the situation at issue because the applicable standard of care was that which the medical profession would have rendered generally in the situation at issue rather than what the expert would have done.

In contrast, the Court of Appeals reversed the trial court and allowed the plaintiff's expert testimony based upon his opinion on the medical records relevant to the case at hand, the expert's own training and experience, and the use of differential diagnosis, even though the medical expert's opinion was not based on clinical studies.[9]
Franklin v. Elmer, 174 Ga. App. 839, 332 S.E.2d 314 (1985).

The need for expert testimony to show lack of due care is one of the hallmarks of a medical malpractice claim. Baskette v. Atlanta Center for Reproductive Medicine, LLC, 285 Ga. App. 876, 648 S.E.2d 100 (2007).

A standard of care expert in a medical malpractice case is subject to cross-examination about the manner in which the expert would have treated the condition at issue. Condra v. Atlanta Orthopaedic Group, P.C., 285 Ga. 667, 681 S.E.2d 152 (2009).
MCG Health, Inc. v. Barton, 285 Ga. App. 577, 647 S.E.2d 81, 221 Ed. Law Rep. 911 (2007).
Piedmont Hosp., Inc. v. Milton, 189 Ga. App. 563, 377 S.E.2d 198 (1988).
Tysinger v. Smisson, 176 Ga. App. 604, 337 S.E.2d 49 (1985).
Stephen W. Brown Radiology Associates v. Gowers, 157 Ga. App. 770, 278 S.E.2d 653 (1981).
McNabb v. Landis, 223 Ga. App. 894, 896, 479 S.E.2d 194 (1996).
Swint v. Alphonse, 348 Ga. App. 199, 820 S.E.2d 312 (2018).
